Description: Pancreatic cancer is highly lethal. A total of 60,430 new cases and 48,220 deaths in the United States were estimated in 2021 (SEER Cancer Stat Facts). The five-year survival continues to be dismal and stands at approximately 7?11%. An earlier diagnosis offers an opportunity to improve the 5-year survival rates, compared with diagnosis at later stages. At present, there are no reliable biomarkers or imaging technology that can detect early-stage pancreatic cancer or accurately identify precursors that are likely to progress to malignancy. This 60-minute special session will provide an overview of the scientific efforts and advances in early detection of pancreatic cancer made under the auspices of NCI Division of Cancer Prevention’s Early Detection Research Network (EDRN) and the Pancreatic Cancer Detection Consortium (PCDC) programs. EDRN provides valuable infrastructure support to many of the sister programs for biomarker validation and informatics. A series of short talks (8 minutes each) will provide a broad programmatic overview for early detection, resources, opportunities for funding, opportunities to collaborate, and a few vignettes to showcase some scientific advancements/new frontiers in the field. The speakers will take questions from the audience at the end of all talks (12 minutes).
